item.title: Italy Restarts American's Murder Trial
item.description: Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito are due to face a new trial on charges of murder and sexual assault for the 2007 killing of British student Meredith Kercher.

item.title: Japan Bank Chief Outlines Deflation Fight
item.description: Japan's new central-bank governor gave the strongest indication yet that he is ready to take previously taboo steps as it embarks on bold easing measures to exit 15 years of deflation.

item.title: Brics Take Steps on Currencies, Bank
item.description: Members of the Brics group of emerging markets took steps to trade their currencies more freely and to establish a joint development bank, seeking to counter the influence that developed countries exert over the global economy.

item.title: Marines Plan Crisis-Response Team
item.description: The U.S. military is making plans to put Marine special-operations teams aboard Navy ships in the Middle East and elsewhere to serve as a rapid-reaction force that could respond to crises.

item.title: EU Regulators to Charge Banks
item.description: European authorities are moving soon to bring a case against some big banks alleging collusion in the $27 trillion market for credit derivatives.

item.title: North Korea Puts Artillery on Alert
item.description: North Korean state media said the country's military command ordered rocket and artillery units be on "highest alert" to strike bases on the U.S. and South Korea.

item.title: Afghanistan: Pakistan Ties Are Fraying
item.description: Afghanistan's relations with Pakistan are growing increasingly strained, Afghan officials say, even as President Hamid Karzai has patched up, for now, his fraying ties with the U.S.

item.title: Israel and Turkey Explore Energy Ties
item.description: Israel's apology to Turkey will boost regional strategic coordination in coping with Syria's civil war, but it also has a compelling economic incentive: the possible export of billions of dollars of Israeli natural-gas reserves to Turkey and beyond, say analysts and officials.

item.title: Singapore to Probe U.S. Engineer's Death
item.description: Singapore's state coroner will start an official inquiry on May 13 into the death of an American engineer found dead in the city-state last year.

item.title: Earthquake Shakes Taiwan
item.description: A 6.1-magnitude earthquake killed at least one person and disrupted operations at some electronics factories in central Taiwan. Aftershocks rattled the area following the quake.

item.title: Spain Struggles to Contain Deficit
item.description: Spain's economy will likely recover at year's end to post modest growth next year, but the country's budget deficit is forecast to remain around current levels, the country's central bank said.

item.title: U.K. Retail Rents Drop as Stores Close
item.description: The collapse of several major British retail chains over the past year already has prompted retail landlords to reduce lease rates to the lowest levels in years.

item.title: U.S. Draws Greater Foreign Investments
item.description: Foreign investments in the U.S. dwarfed American investments abroad by the biggest margin on record last year, leaving the U.S. more vulnerable to external shocks but suggesting the nation remains a magnet for foreign funds.

item.title: Rebel Chief Claims Power in Central Africa
item.description: The de facto leader of Central African Republic rebels claimed control of the impoverished, mineral-rich nation after driving the president into exile, dissolving the constitution and declaring himself ruler for at least three years.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Take Seat at Summit
item.description: Syria's opposition coalition occupied the country's seat at a summit of heads of state in Qatar at its host's invitation, drawing warnings from some Arab states.

item.title: U.S. Warns on Myanmar Travel
item.description: The U.S. Embassy has warned against travel to parts of Myanmar after deadly clashes between majority Buddhists and minority Muslims leave at least 40 people dead.

item.title: Breivik Barred From Mother's Funeral
item.description: A request by convicted Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik to attend his mother's funeral was turned down by prison officials.

item.title: Rwandan Warlord Appears Before Criminal Court
item.description: A Rwandan-born warlord said he was innocent of charges including murder, rape, pillaging and using child soldiers in eastern Congo at his first appearance before the International Criminal Court.

item.title: Australia to Pull Out of Afghanistan This Year
item.description: Australia said it will withdraw most of its troops from Afghanistan by year-end, after the base from which they operate closes.

item.title: 'Sticker Lady' Faces Mischief Charge
item.description: A street artist accused of putting quirky messages on stickers around the city-state, was charged with mischief, which carries a lighter penalty than vandalism.

item.title: Indian State Wants to Ban Sri Lankan Cricketers
item.description: The state government of Tamil Nadu doesn't want cricketers or umpires from Sri Lanka to feature in Indian Premier League matches scheduled in the state's capital, ramping up anti-Sri Lankan rhetoric for alleged abuses against Tamils.

item.title: Cyprus Sets Bank Restructuring
item.description: Cyprus gave the first indications of the steep losses facing large deposit holders at the island's two biggest lenders, as bank workers demonstrated outside the central bank and demanded the governor's resignation.

item.title: Amid Crisis, Cypriots Look Inward
item.description: Cyprus's contentious bailout negotiations have brought out residents' impulses toward self-reliance, as food donations rise and families make plans for unemployed members.

item.title: Cyprus Bank Crisis
item.description: The bailout deal for Cyprus saved the country from crashing out of the euro, but it came at the cost of widening the political mistrust between the strong economies of Europe's north and the weaklings of the south. See key dates in the Cypriot crisis.

item.title: Rebuilt India Enjoys Test Revival
item.description: India's cricketers find new batting order, while England and Australia face issues ahead of this year's Ashes.

item.title: U.S. Soccer Could Use a Good Crisis
item.description: A loss by the U.S. men's soccer team in Mexico on Tuesday would likely revive concerns that this side isn't good enough to make it through an increasingly competitive regional qualifying tournament.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: Shards of a Reputation
item.description: The Israel Museum celebrates a half-century archaeological effort and historical exploration with "Herod the Great: The King's Final Journey."

item.title: Reaching Out to Touch Space
item.description: An ambitious survey at the Kemper Art Museum presents an impressive selection of works by Georges Braque, who transformed traditional pictorial space into Cubism's unstable planes.

item.title: Guards, Drones to Protect India's Rhinos
item.description: Authorities in India's Kaziranga national park are taking a more muscular approach to combat poachers who have killed 22 one-horned rhinos in the park last year.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 26
item.description: In today's pictures, a man searches for sheep trapped in the snow in Ireland, men embrace during Holy Week in Spain, an injured man lies on a bed in Afghanistan, and more.

item.title: Arms Race to Grow World's Hottest Pepper Goes Nuclear
item.description: The chili one-upmanship raises the question of how many people can actually appreciate the march toward new heights of heat.
